content.webTitle: Devon Alexander hopes to raise spirits in Ferguson by beating Amir Khan

fields.headline: Devon Alexander hopes to raise spirits in Ferguson by beating Amir Khan
fields.bodyText: For Devon Alexander, inspiration lies tragically close to home. The 27-year-old St Louis native was raised just 20 minutes from Ferguson, a city which has endured the gaze of the world following the shooting of unarmed 18-year-old Michael Brown by police officer Darren Wilson in August. Alexander himself had a typically tough upbringing – “I was raised in the ghetto. I saw things kids shouldn’t see” – yet when he walks out here on Saturday night to face Amir Khan in their WBC welterweight title fight, the anger, hurt and devastation which has sparked violent outrage among his friends and family will only serve to fire up his bid to shock the Briton. When he looks to where his entourage will be sat at the MGM Grand, there will be one special guest whose presence will resonate like no other. Michael Brown Sr, whose son’s death has triggered such an outpouring of grief and civil unrest, will be ringside. “We’re going to represent St Louis the way we always represent St Louis,” said Alexander’s trainer Kevin Cunningham. “We are going to have Mike Brown Sr with us, so that’s pretty much what we’re doing in a nutshell in reference to that.” For Ferguson-raised Cunningham, though, dealing with the pain of violence and social hardships is nothing new. He first met Alexander when he was a police officer in St Louis who had started an after-school boxing programme. “It started out as trying to make a difference to these kids,” he said. “I first came across Devon when he was seven. He was the same happy-go-lucky, snotty-nosed kid he is now. “It’s saddened me to see what has happened in Ferguson. I hope things can get better.” Cunningham opened a restaurant in Ferguson last month called Knockouts. On the opening night a man tried to force his way and was stopped by bouncer Herb Burnett. Soon after, Burnett was shot in the head. A man has been charged with first-degree murder. The day after it emerged that the police officer who shot Brown would not face state criminal charges, looters tried to ransack the restaurant, which was closed out of respect for the bouncer. Cunningham sat inside with his security staff and waited. “We were there to protect our business,” he said. “We figured the looters were coming, and they started burning everything down. About 10 minutes before midnight, you had 50 carloads of young guys pull up in front of the place. “We walked out with guns in hand and they stopped and one of them said: ‘Oh, OK. We see you guys are ready.’ They drove off and then went down, two doors down, and shot all over that place, a shoe store. They kicked the windows in but they couldn’t get in so they drove off. I have 50 high-def TVs and a great sound system and I guess they were coming to loot us and take all the TVs.” To see Alexander navigate away from a life of crime to establish himself as a world-class athlete gives Cunningham, a close friend of Khan’s trainer Virgil Hunter, immense pride. “He was one of the few who stayed focused and stuck with the programme. He persevered and that’s why he is where he is today. A lot of my kids fell by the wayside,” he said. “The young kids look up to Devon big time because he does all the speaking in schools. He does that all the time. He’s all about giving back. “I got a lot of kids who I’ve tried to help come up to me who messed up real bad and say: ‘Man, I wished I had listened to you.’” Alexander has certainly been doing a great deal of listening of his own in the buildup to arguably the biggest fight of his life. Khan’s talk about finally getting the chance to dethrone Floyd Mayweather before a punch has been thrown has angered the softly spoken southpaw. This is, after all, a fighter with some pedigree. Hailed as a boxing child prodigy, he was a phenomenal amateur, amassing a stack of triumphs before turning professional in 2004 at the age of 17. Five years later his first title arrived in the shape of the WBC light-welterweight belt in 2009 before losing it two years later to Tim Bradley. It was another three years until Alexander was crowned king once more, beating Randall Bailey to win the IBF welterweight title – only to be dethroned 14 months later. His comeback has been steady. The 27-year-old exudes confidence with no blasts of bravado and is adamant there will be only one person looking forward to potentially meeting Mayweather. “In my opinion, someone who’s good doesn’t have to gloat about it,” he said of Khan. “He doesn’t have to say he’s good. That’s cocky in my opinion. Those are the ones who fall pretty easy. I haven’t been around him too much, but it’s not good to be cocky. I hear about him a lot and I hear from fans over in the UK where he’s from that he’s arrogant. A lot of people hate him. This is the feedback I’m getting and it’s not good to be like that. “What does he do that I can’t do? I guess they have to say something good that he does, but I do the same things he does, so this is definitely a 50-50 fight. “When you got talent and speed, it’s hard to beat speed, but once somebody figures you out and knows how to beat you, then you’ve got problems. “You don’t want people to think you are arrogant. You don’t want people to say you think you’re better than everybody. Where I come from, we believe you’re not better than anybody.” As Ferguson yearns for hope, its shattered residents will look to Alexander to provide some hard-fought respite.
